title: 111_hr2324
content: The Act titled "Gun Show Loophole Closing Act of 2009" aims to address background checks at gun shows. The Congress finds that approximately 5,200 gun shows are held annually in the US, attracting many attendees and firearms sellers. These shows provide easy access for criminals and prohibited persons to obtain firearms without background checks or traceable records. The term 'gun show' is defined as an event where 50 or more firearms are offered for sale, exchange, or transfer, with exceptions for private sales at an individual's residence and events with fewer than 100 firearms. The term 'gun show vendor' refers to a person who is not licensed under section 923 and exhibits, sells, offers for sale, transfers, or exchanges a firearm at a gun show, regardless of arrangements with the gun show operator. Gun shows with not more than 100 firearms can be conducted by private, not-for-profit organizations for hunting activities, attended only by members and their immediate families. Regulation of firearms transfers at gun shows includes defining a 'gun show vendor' as someone not licensed under section 923 who sells, exhibits, or exchanges firearms at a gun show. Gun show operators must be at least 21 years old and comply with specific regulations. Gun show operators must be at least 21 years old, not prohibited from transporting firearms interstate, have not violated any laws, and must register with the Attorney General. Gun show operators must register with the Attorney General by providing fingerprints, a photograph, meeting certain requirements, disclosing all necessary information truthfully, and paying a registration fee determined by the Attorney General. Gun show operators must notify the Attorney General of the details of the gun show and the vendors, verify the identity of vendors before the show begins, and pay a registration fee determined by the Attorney General. Before the gun show begins, the person who will be a vendor must verify their identity by showing a valid ID with a photo, sign a ledger with identifying information, and sign a notice outlining their obligations as a gun show vendor. The gun show vendor must verify their identity, sign a ledger with identifying information, and receive a notice outlining their obligations. Records must be maintained to demonstrate compliance with regulations set by the Attorney General. The Attorney General requires compliance with regulations for transferring firearms between unlicensed persons at gun shows, including recording firearm details and transaction information. Licensed importers, manufacturers, or dealers must record firearm details and transaction information as required by the Attorney General. They must also notify the parties involved that a background check has been conducted and provide a unique identification number to ensure compliance with federal and state laws. Licensed importers, manufacturers, or dealers must submit a report to the Attorney General within 10 days of a firearm transfer, detailing the make, model, and serial number of the firearm. They must also retain a record of the transfer, excluding personal information of unlicensed individuals involved. Licensed importers, manufacturers, or dealers must submit a report to the Attorney General within 10 days of a firearm transfer, detailing the make, model, and serial number of the firearm. They must retain a record of the transfer, including relevant information, as part of their permanent business records. The Attorney General cannot impose recordkeeping requirements on gun show vendors under this section. Penalties for knowingly violating certain subsections of section 932 include fines and imprisonment up to 5 years. Whoever knowingly violates subsections of section 932 may face fines and imprisonment up to 5 years. Additionally, the Attorney General has the authority to suspend or revoke the registration of individuals who violate these provisions. The Attorney General can suspend or revoke the registration of individuals who knowingly violate section 932, and impose a civil fine of up to $10,000. The Attorney General has the authority to inspect gun show operators' records and inventory to ensure compliance with firearm transfer regulations. The Attorney General can inspect gun show operators and licensees for compliance without needing reasonable cause or a warrant. There are increased penalties for serious recordkeeping violations by licensees. Licensees who knowingly make false statements or violate certain sections of the law will face fines and imprisonment. The severity of the penalty depends on the nature of the offense. Licensees who violate criminal background check requirements may face increased penalties, including fines and imprisonment for up to 10 years. Additionally, the authority to hire personnel to inspect gun shows is granted. The Director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives may hire additional personnel to inspect gun shows and submit biennial reports to Congress on firearm sales at these shows. Congress will receive biennial reports on firearm sales at gun shows, including details on how firearms are sold, if background checks are conducted, needed resources, and recommendations for improvements. This section and its amendments will take effect 180 days after enactment.
